commit_message:
Remove unneeded 'create' from all tags sections

Look for all keys that begin with 'refs/tags' rather than just the
string literal 'refs/tags/*' when removing unneeded create permissions
from tag access sections.

Change-Id: I6dc226065166038700ffd324d354e617596888cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/53/169853/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for key in acl: if key.startswith('access "refs/tags/'): acl[key] = [ x for x in acl[key] if not x.startswith('create = ')]
deleted_lines: try: acl['access "refs/tags/*"'] = [ x for x in acl['access "refs/tags/*"'] if not x.startswith('create = ')] except KeyError: pass

commit_message:
Add tempest + postgres job for manila

Right now Manila project is tested in CI only against MySQL DB backend.

Add new tempest job, similar to existing one, but with different
DB backend - PostgreSQL. Set it as non-voting until it becomes stable.

Change-Id: I56cbdd8173bcbc906772457bdcbbebc27c742cfe

commit_message:
Change default Ceph log file name to '$cluster-$name.log'

There is a possibility that an OSD host will run many OSD deamons, so it
is better idea to log messages to different files.

Change-Id: Ief8186006386af8ae7e40cffeeaeef5a5c0f3c70
Closes-Bug: 1428693

commit_message:
read ip from eth1 if using host-only network

If the the vms are using host-only network, then eth1 would be the
proper interface to retrieve ip of the vm. Without these lines, the
host manager will only add 127.0.0.1 to /etc/hosts file.

Change-Id: If2f825ebb9d6f7f096ce55e1bf070e5af91f5d45
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-vagrant refs/changes/85/168585/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if conf["use_bridge"] == false config.hostmanager.ip_resolver = proc do |machine| result = "" machine.communicate.execute("ifconfig eth1") do |type, data| result << data if type == :stdout end (ip = /inet addr:(\d+\.\d+\.\d+\.\d+)/.match(result)) && ip[1] end end

commit_message:
Align patching tests with Fuel 6.1

Make necessary changes in tests to be able
to run them on Fuel 6.1 iso.
Also change parser for erratum.yaml, so it
recognize new modified format.

Change-Id: I6c8299aa6bda1fad1fb1f8c26338a86bf7c709ae
Implements: blueprint mos-patching-tests

commit_message:
Rework authentication

Saharaclient's authentication is relatively simple. It resolves the
sahara URL and the token prior to making any requests.

Provide the means to use the features of the adapter directly and adopt
those features.

Change-Id: I7d0f8435b836d187a0396657b485d9d080a59ba1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-saharaclient refs/changes/73/147773/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Copyright (c) 2013 Mirantis Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import requests class HTTPClient(object): def __init__(self, base_url, token): self.base_url = base_url self.token = token def get(self, url): return requests.get(self.base_url + url, headers={'x-auth-token': self.token}) def post(self, url, body, json=True): headers = {'x-auth-token': self.token} if json: headers['content-type'] = 'application/json' return requests.post(self.base_url + url, body, headers=headers) def put(self, url, body, json=True): headers = {'x-auth-token': self.token} if json: headers['content-type'] = 'application/json' return requests.put(self.base_url + url, body, headers=headers) def delete(self, url): return requests.delete(self.base_url + url, headers={'x-auth-token': self.token})

commit_message:
Fixes image building, CI tests and requirements

[DIB] Add posibility to build image from specified commit of agent
Included gitpython, required by file-downloading feature
Incorrect generation of file path where to put script symlink caused
"OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory" exception to be raised
after first execution plan run

Change-Id: Ifb6dffde5afd5ad5ce363934be71c7cc1e046de2
Closes-Bug: #1439367
Closes-Bug: #1439767
Co-Authored-By: Stan Lagun <slagun@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Kirill Zaitsev <kzaitsev@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Clean-up extra first sentence, tab markup

-Remove first line of text in file.  It
does not belong in this file.
-Change double asterisk markup in
View resource statistics procedure.  Replace with
:guilabel:`<tab name>`.  This will
produce italic text instead of bold text.

commit_message:
Prevent plugin package deletion before API unregister call

If plugin has been used in some enviroment, we should show
error and do not delete his package:

    400 Client Error: Bad Request (Can't delete plugin which is enabledfor some environment.)

Change-Id: Id0686a6332d8312d49556fdb43c66b82b4370ef4
Closes-Bug: #1430768
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/80/169280/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cls.unregister(plugin_name, plugin_version) return plugin.remove(plugin_name, plugin_version)

commit_message:
Master node UID hack

Needed for UI to map React/Backbone models
correctly on Master Node settings.

Part of Tracking feature - we need to show Master Node UID
on Support tab, but UI couldn't easily parse default settings
format. It was easier to add hack on backend rather than dance
with Javascript.

Change-Id: I298360148ffe894ade65bf8393e3d5ba3ced86b6

commit_message:
Provide a way to know the boostrap_nodeid IP

Currently it is possible to know what is the hostname of the boostrap
nodeid but not its IP. Since depending on the use case the use of the IP
might be needed, a way to have access to this information should be
provided.

Change-Id: I9d0a7ee7de2088ddb87e0d8a8ae2b3ac75b0e78d

subject: Logging not using oslo.i18n guidelines
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-18 02:33:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-brick/commit/59dbfc6951b7563f7c262d2419327e707aae8fc6', 'message': 'Logging not using oslo.i18n guidelines

As part of cleanup in Cinder there have been quite a few
instances found where the i18n guidelines are not being
followed. I believe this has helped lead to some of the
confusion around how to correctly do this. Other developers
see this code and assume it is an example of the correct
usage.

This patch attempts to clean up most of those violations
in the existing codebase to hopefully help avoid some of
that confusion in reviews.

Some issues address:
* Correct log translation markers for different log levels
* Passing format values as arguments to call, not preformatting
* Not forcing translation via six.text_type and others

Guidelines can be found here:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html

Will add hacking checks in the future if they are enabled for
this project. Hacking checks would not be able to identify all
violations of the guidelines, but it could be useful for catching
obvious ones suck as LOG.info("No markers!").

Change-Id: I4d0243b3aa9852743e51d7f01a481aefc3c620a8

commit_message:
Logging not using oslo.i18n guidelines

As part of cleanup in Cinder there have been quite a few
instances found where the i18n guidelines are not being
followed. I believe this has helped lead to some of the
confusion around how to correctly do this. Other developers
see this code and assume it is an example of the correct
usage.

This patch attempts to clean up most of those violations
in the existing codebase to hopefully help avoid some of
that confusion in reviews.

Some issues address:
* Correct log translation markers for different log levels
* Passing format values as arguments to call, not preformatting
* Not forcing translation via six.text_type and others

Guidelines can be found here:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html

Will add hacking checks in the future if they are enabled for
this project. Hacking checks would not be able to identify all
violations of the guidelines, but it could be useful for catching
obvious ones such as LOG.info("No markers!").

Change-Id: I4d0243b3aa9852743e51d7f01a481aefc3c620a8
Partial-bug: 1433216
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/76/165276/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from os_brick.i18n import _, _LE msg = _LE("Exception in string format operation. msg='%s'") LOG.exception(msg, self.message) for name, value in kwargs.iteritems(): # Log string can't be localized, but still marking it # in case we want to enforce checks. LOG.error(_LE("%(n)s: %(v)s"), {'n': name, 'v': value})
deleted_lines: from os_brick.i18n import _ msg = (_("Exception in string format operation. msg='%s'") % self.message) LOG.exception(msg) for name, value in kwargs.iteritems(): LOG.error("%s: %s" % (name, value))

commit_message:
Import nova's wrapper for nice testr output

Bring in the wrapper script the nova team uses so it is easier for other
projects to share. The subunit-trace command run by the script is part
of tempest-lib, so add that to our test-requirements.txt. We can't add
it to the main requirements list because tempest-lib also depends on
oslotest.

Change-Id: If14d96832f8ddc3130608abab3223aa2add7bec8

commit_message:
Use my_ip as default URL instead of localhost

python-openstackclient for ironic-discoverd fails like:
 $ openstack baremetal introspection status <uuid>
 ERROR: openstack 'utf8' codec can't decode byte 0xa5 in position 89:
 invalid start byte

When set "DISCOVERD_URL" environment value as http://<my_ip>:5050,
this error doesn't occur.
So that, the reason of this error is using localhost as default url.

This patch set fix the default url to host's URL.

Change-Id: I59e6bf30c19eee65b52e8d2bd56c148cd3b29efa
Closes-Bug: #1439468

commit_message:
Make the msgpackutils handlers more extendable

This change revamps the current serialization and
deserialization functions to be tiny objects that
have the ability to serialize there expected types.

It also adds a registry of these handlers objects
and allows for passing a registry into the dumps
and loads methods for people that want to add there
own handlers on.

Change-Id: Ib1a8a507c6c3d4f0372114d67163d3f2ab495c9f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.serialization refs/changes/13/156013/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import functoolsclass HandlerRegistry(object): min_value = 0 max_value = 127 def __init__(self): self._handlers = {} def __iter__(self): return six.itervalues(self._handlers) def register(self, handler): ident = handler.identity if ident < self.min_value: raise ValueError("Handler '%s' identity must be greater" " or equal to %s" % (handler, self.min_value)) if ident > self.max_value: raise ValueError("Handler '%s' identity must be less than" " or equal to %s" % (handler, self.max_value)) if ident in self._handlers: raise ValueError("Already registered handler with" " identity %s: %s" % (ident, self._handlers[ident])) else: self._handlers[ident] = handler def __len__(self): return len(self._handlers) def get(self, identity): return self._handlers.get(identity, None) def match(self, obj): for handler in six.itervalues(self._handlers): if isinstance(obj, handler.handles): return handler return None class UUIDHandler(object): identity = 0 handles = (uuid.UUID,) def serialize(self, obj): return six.text_type(obj.hex).encode('ascii') def deserialize(self, data): return uuid.UUID(hex=six.text_type(data, encoding='ascii')) class DateTimeHandler(object): identity = 1 handles = (datetime.datetime,) def __init__(self, registry): self._registry = registry def serialize(self, dt): dct = { 'day': dt.day, 'month': dt.month, 'year': dt.year, 'hour': dt.hour, 'minute': dt.minute, 'second': dt.second, 'microsecond': dt.microsecond, } if dt.tzinfo: dct['tz'] = dt.tzinfo.tzname(None) return dumps(dct, registry=self._registry) def deserialize(self, blob): dct = loads(blob, registry=self._registry) dt = datetime.datetime(day=dct['day'], month=dct['month'], year=dct['year'], hour=dct['hour'], minute=dct['minute'], second=dct['second'], microsecond=dct['microsecond']) if 'tz' in dct: tzinfo = timezone(dct['tz']) dt = tzinfo.localize(dt) return dt class CountHandler(object): identity = 2 handles = (itertools.count,) def serialize(self, obj): return msgpack.packb([start, step]) def deserialize(self, data): start, step = value if not _PY26: return itertools.count(start, step) else: if step != 1: raise ValueError("Python 2.6.x does not support steps" " that are not equal to one") return itertools.count(start) if netaddr is not None: class NetAddrIPHandler(object): identity = 3 handles = commit_message:
Expand valid server group name character set

Names requested for a server group should use the same validation
checking as names in the other APIS. Right now it will not allow
any non alphanumeric characters. Change this to allow all printable
and horizontal whitespace unicode characters. This is the same check
that is done for flavor names, as well as names in v2.1 APIs.
Closes-Bug: #1434335

Change-Id: I6c675fb6c2f40e83499a41ecdccec58d99501433
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/164308/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revert of gateways for VIPs

This commit sets default route for public interfaces
and also sets static routes for haproxy namespaces to
the networks which are connected to the host directly
with metric of 10000 to ensure that these routes do
not override routes installed by kernel on interfaces
configuration stage

Regression caused by fix of
https://bugs.launchpad.net/fuel/+bug/1433150

Change-Id: I7df8efad4aa119896314e77c29d9b024599dc865
Closes-Bug: 1431547

commit_message:
Extended check for 'ceph-osd' that doesn't have a parent host.

If ceph-ods creation process is interrupted, then one of ceph-osd
can be added not correctly and will not have a parent node.

Change-Id: I8c447072d2309c7017209e5478228719bc65ede6
Closes-Bug: #1437990

added_lines: osd_ids = get_osd_ids(remote) for node in disks_tree['stray']: if node['type'] == 'osd' and node['id'] in osd_ids: logger.info("WARNING! Ceph OSD '{0}' has no parent host!". format(node['name'])) assert_equal(node['status'], 'up', 'OSD node {0} is down'. format(node['id']))@logwrap def get_osd_ids(remote): cmd = 'ceph osd ls -f json' return json.loads(''.join(remote.execute(cmd)['stdout']))

commit_message:
Allow node interfaces update if it's in 'discover' or 'error' state

Node inferfaces update is allowed when node is in one of the following states:
'discover', 'error'. It's locked for other node states.
It's not locked on node creation, i.e. when node.nic_interfaces is empty yet.

Closes-Bug: #1425901
Closes-Bug: #1428776
Change-Id: Icc60c432296c28e89d71b1fd0dd864870553a467

commit_message:
Bump last version of ceilometer-client

All Ceilometer resources in Heat can not be used 
(created, deleted, ...) if ceilometerclient has version 1.0.12.
So it leads to blocking autoscaling mechanism, where ceilometer's
resources are used.
It happens due to huge time interval between 1.0.12 and 1.0.13 
ceilometerclient versions. 
This change change lower version from 1.0.12 to 1.0.13, which fix 
mentioned above issue.


Change-Id: I670e0d4dd98b087e0f87696b0c28044f1b4d9c00
Closes-Bug: #1423291

added_lines: python-ceilometerclient>=1.0.13

commit_message:
Fix functional test using local timeout value

The ovsdb monitor test was using a timeout of 60s for monitor start.
This change sets the timeout to the global timeout value if it is
greater (it's 90s currently).

Closes-bug: #1439914

Change-Id: I95ee3d7dfdb5f010347a9d8db1b2bf610c0289d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/27/170327/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix typo in neutron.conf.j2

Currently, neutron.conf.j2 tries to do a substitution on $(tenant_id)s
but this should be %(tenant_id)s.  This results in some 404s as neutron
ends up trying to hit
http://<ip>:8774/v2/%(tenant_id)s/<tenant_id>/os-server-external-events
instead of http://<ip>:8774/v2/<tenant_id>/os-server-external-events.

Change-Id: Ia70d93d2f1057795a0ba197da4421f0fc2639cd2
Closes-Bug: #1439748
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/77/170177/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adjust ResourcesController to provide get_all()

When using index() a request to /v1/resource will redirect to
/v1/resources/ and then give information. Since we don't appear to
be redirecting to trailing slashes anywhere else, this appear to be an
inconsistency we don't want.

Change-Id: I6d8a94b36093d4cfae31ad1a10d3da10e1fa1683

commit_message:
Fixes bug in Federation list projects endpoint

'/OS-FEDERATION/projects' and '/auth/projects'
API endpoints did not honor project inherited
group role assignments.

This patch fixed this bug.

Closes-Bug: #1424500

Change-Id: I4937289362122952d1b3e1b73c5712601c675bb4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/13/169113/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Inherited role assignments are enabled. If there is an inherited role # assignment on a domain, add in all the projects in that domain. If # there is an inherited role assignments on a project, add in all the # subprojects under that project in the hierarchy. parents_ids = self.driver.list_project_ids_for_groups( group_ids, driver_hints.Hints(), inherited=True) subproject_ids = [] for parent_id in parents_ids: subtree = self.resource_api.list_projects_in_subtree(parent_id) subproject_ids += [subproject['id'] for subproject in subtree] list(set(project_ids + project_ids_from_domains + subproject_ids)))
deleted_lines: # Inherited roles are enabled, so check to see if these groups have any # roles on any domain, in which case we must add in all the projects # in that domain. list(set(project_ids + project_ids_from_domains)))

commit_message:
Exposes bug in Federation list projects endpoint

'/OS-FEDERATION/projects' and '/auth/projects'
API endpoints do not honor project inherited
group role assignments.

This patch exposes this bug and a follow-on patch
will fix it.

Related-Bug: #1424500

Change-Id: Idd6827bc5552192f04de19e8a78fb462bdde380f

added_lines: from keystone.tests.unit import utils self.project_inherited['id'], self.subproject_inherited['id']]), self.project_inherited['id'], self.subproject_inherited['id']])) @utils.wip('waiting on bug #1424500') def test_list_projects_for_inherited_project_assignment(self): # Enable OS-INHERIT config switch self.config_fixture.config(group='os_inherit', enabled=True) # Replace the existing domain inherited assignment by a project one self.assignment_api.delete_grant( role_id=self.role_customer['id'], group_id=self.group_customers['id'], domain_id=self.domainD['id'], inherited_to_projects=True) self.assignment_api.create_grant( role_id=self.role_customer['id'], group_id=self.group_customers['id'], project_id=self.project_inherited['id'], inherited_to_projects=True) # Define expected projects from customer assertion, which contain # the subproject of the project with the inherited assignment above expected_project_ids = [self.proj_customers['id'], self.subproject_inherited['id']] # Assert expected projects for both available URLs for url in ('/OS-FEDERATION/projects', '/auth/projects'): r = self.get(url, token=self.tokens['CUSTOMER_ASSERTION']) project_ids = [project['id'] for project in r.result['projects']] self.assertEqual(project_ids, expected_project_ids, 'Projects match failed for url %s' % url) # Replace the project inherited assignment by the previous domain one self.assignment_api.delete_grant( role_id=self.role_customer['id'], group_id=self.group_customers['id'], project_id=self.project_inherited['id'], inherited_to_projects=True) self.assignment_api.create_grant( role_id=self.role_customer['id'], group_id=self.group_customers['id'], domain_id=self.domainD['id'], inherited_to_projects=True) self.subproject_inherited = self.new_project_ref( domain_id=self.domainD['id'], parent_id=self.project_inherited['id']) self.resource_api.create_project(self.subproject_inherited['id'], self.subproject_inherited)

commit_message:
Fix invalid operation on NICs in performance tests

One of performance tests was trying to change NICs for nodes
in 'ready' state which now is not possible.
Nodes will be now in 'discover' state for this test.

Change-Id: I61f0193d5df0f75ad8a210489f6aa27be3f82342
Closes-Bug: #1439540
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/29/170029/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # node's nics can be changed only in discover or error state for node in self.env.nodes: node.status = consts.NODE_STATUSES.discover self.env.db.flush()

commit_message:
Raise exception when backup volume-backed instance

This patch will be backported to Juno and Icehouse so that
Nova can fail immediately to let user know that it's not
supported in that release.

Partial-Bug: #1313573

Change-Id: Ic84fa9e0b9c2d7b6cf49955aa4f0d44ade2b5397

commit_message:
Cleanup use of .driver

Unless being used to override the Manager implementation, .driver
doesn't need to be used because the Manager automatically
forwards calls to the driver. The code shouldn't use .driver
directly where it's not necessary since developers should be
able to override behavior in the Manager, which we've done
several times (for deprecations or reorganization for
example).

Change-Id: I05b13d4f4ec7e6be8e72b73bac164333535aebee

commit_message:
Ignore 404 error and lower a warning log to info

Ignore an expected 404 error. Lower the severity of an informational log entry
from warning to info to avoid polluting the server.log

Conflicts:
	neutron/plugins/bigswitch/servermanager.py

Closes-Bug: #1413457
Change-Id: Ib6316cdda0aed10d8f430790b0c4f909ad833eb0
(cherry picked from commit 705b76d02db318ecedcbd96d09af9785f14429ee)

added_lines: from senlin.common import sdk # A credential should include either userid or username # and user_domain_id to identify a unique user. It also # contains the password and auth_url for WebhookMiddleware # to do authentication. self._authenticate(req) def _authenticate(self, req): token_id = self._get_token(credential) def _get_token(self, credential): try: access_info = sdk.authenticate(**credential) token_id = access_info.auth_token except Exception as ex: msg = "Webhook get token failed: %s" % ex.message LOG.error(msg) # TODO(Yanyan Hu): raise WebhookUnauthenticated # exception here. raise Exception(msg)
deleted_lines: from oslo.serialization import jsonutils as jsonimport requestsfrom senlin.common import exception auth_uri = ''.join([cfg.CONF.keystone_authtoken.auth_uri, '/auth/tokens']) self._authorize(req, auth_uri) def _authorize(self, req, auth_uri): token_id = self._get_token(credential, auth_uri) def _get_token(self, credential, auth_uri): # TODO(Yanyan Hu): Using sdk rather then # requests to get token from keystone. if 'userid' in credential: user_info = { 'id': credential['userid'], 'password': credential['password'] } elif 'username' in credential and 'domain' in credential: user_info = { 'domain': {"id": credential['domain']}, 'name': credential['username'], 'password': credential['password'] } else: msg = "Either userid or both username and domain" + \ "have to be specified in webhook credential." # TODO(Yanyan Hu): raise webhook credential exception raise Exception(msg) creds = { 'auth': { 'identity': { "methods": ["password"], "password": { "user": user_info } } } } creds_json = json.dumps(creds) headers = {'Content-Type': 'application/json'} LOG.debug(_('Authenticating with %s for webhook req'), auth_uri) try: response = requests.post(auth_uri, data=creds_json, headers=headers) headers = response.headers token_id = headers['x-subject-token'] except Exception: LOG.error(_LE("Webhook get token failed %s."), response.json()) raise exception.AuthorizationFailure()

commit_message:
Remove 'tenant' from RequestContext

This patch completely removes 'tenant' from the RequestContext.
Now we should be able to detect where the old-style references are
still alive.

Change-Id: I699d8cff5db3f7af0887f12eb1dc1ffa86ab1161

commit_message:
Warn if boot volume AZ differs from instance AZ

For the Launch Instance source step, this patch adds the availability
zone column to the transfer table when a volume is selected as a boot
source. It also will display a warning icon next to the volume's AZ
name if it differs than the selected instance AZ. When hovering over
the warning icon it will reveal a toolip reminding the user to ensure
the selected AZ is compatible with the volume AZ.

Closes-Bug: 1437535
Change-Id: I2f5f2672d976bfb274d7dfe22f455fd2cab823d5

Add migrated content for trove CLI chapter-5

This commit covers the manage_db_config
section of section_cli_trove.xml

Change-Id: Ic19cdfe17c537098d32ffb43e0e0ee93e859c7f0
Partial-Bug: #1419134
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/02/169002/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================= Manage database configuration ============================= You can manage database configuration tasks by using configuration groups. Configuration groups let you set configuration options, in bulk, on one or more databases. This example assumes you have created a MySQL database and shows you how to use a configuration group to configure it. Although this example sets just one option on one database, you can use these same procedures to set multiple options on multiple database instances throughout your environment. This can provide significant time savings in managing your cloud. Bulk-configure a database or databases ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ #. **List available options** First, determine which configuration options you can set. Different data store versions have different configuration options. List the names and IDs of all available versions of the ``mysql`` data store: .. code:: $ trove datastore-version-list mysql +--------------------------------------+-----------+ | id | name | +--------------------------------------+-----------+ | eeb574ce-f49a-48b6-820d-b2959fcd38bb | mysql-5.5 | +--------------------------------------+-----------+ Pass in the data store version ID with the trove ``configuration-parameter-list`` command to get the available options: .. code:: $ trove configuration-parameter-list DATASTORE_VERSION_ID +--------------------------------+---------+---------+----------------------+------------------+ | name | type | min | max | restart_required | +--------------------------------+---------+---------+----------------------+------------------+ | auto_increment_increment | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | auto_increment_offset | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | autocommit | integer | 0 | 1 | False | | bulk_insert_buffer_size | integer | 0 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | character_set_client | string | | | False | | character_set_connection | string | | | False | | character_set_database | string | | | False | | character_set_filesystem | string | | | False | | character_set_results | string | | | False | | character_set_server | string | | | False | | collation_connection | string | | | False | | collation_database | string | | | False | | collation_server | string | | | False | | connect_timeout | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | expire_logs_days | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | innodb_buffer_pool_size | integer | 0 | 68719476736 | True | | innodb_file_per_table | integer | 0 | 1 | True | | innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit | integer | 0 | 2 | False | | innodb_log_buffer_size | integer | 1048576 | 4294967296 | True | | innodb_open_files | integer | 10 | 4294967296 | True | | innodb_thread_concurrency | integer | 0 | 1000 | False | | interactive_timeout | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | join_buffer_size | integer | 0 | 4294967296 | False | | key_buffer_size | integer | 0 | 4294967296 | False | | local_infile | integer | 0 | 1 | False | | max_allowed_packet | integer | 1024 | 1073741824 | False | | max_connect_errors | integer | 1 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | max_connections | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | max_user_connections | integer | 1 | 100000 | False | | myisam_sort_buffer_size | integer | 4 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | server_id | integer | 1 | 100000 | True | | sort_buffer_size | integer | 32768 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | sync_binlog | integer | 0 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | wait_timeout | integer | 1 | 31536000 | False | +--------------------------------+---------+---------+----------------------+------------------+ In this example, the ``configuration-parameter-list`` command returns a list of options that work with MySQL 5.5. #. **Create a configuration group** A configuration group contains a comma-separated list of key-value pairs. Each pair consists of a configuration option and its value. You can create a configuration group by using the trove ``configuration-create`` command. The general syntax for this command is: .. code:: $ trove configuration-create NAME VALUES --datastore DATASTORE_NAME - *NAME*. The name you want to use for this group. - *VALUES*. The list of key-value pairs. - *DATASTORE_NAME*. The name of the associated data store. Set *VALUES* as a JSON dictionary, for example: .. code:: {"myFirstKey" : "someString", "mySecondKey" : someInt} This example creates a configuration group called ``group1``. ``group1`` contains just one key and value pair, and this pair sets the ``sync_binlog`` option to ``1``. .. code:: $ trove configuration-create group1 '{"sync_binlog" : 1}' --datastore mysql +----------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +----------------------+--------------------------------------+ | datastore_version_id | eeb574ce-f49a-48b6-820d-b2959fcd38bb | | description | None | | id | 9a9ef3bc-079b-476a-9cbf-85aa64f898a5 | | name | group1 | | values | {"sync_binlog": 1} | +----------------------+--------------------------------------+ #. **Examine your existing configuration** Before you use the newly-created configuration group, look at how the ``sync_binlog`` option is configured on your database. Replace the following sample connection values with values that connect to your database: .. code:: $ mysql -u user7 -ppassword -h 172.16.200.2 myDB7 Welcome to the MySQL monitor. Commands end with ; or \g. ... mysql> show variables like 'sync_binlog'; +---------------+-------+ | Variable_name | Value | +---------------+-------+ | sync_binlog | 0 | +---------------+-------+ As you can see, the ``sync_binlog`` option is currently set to ``0`` for the ``myDB7`` database. #. **Change the database configuration using a configuration group** You can change a database's configuration by attaching a configuration group to a database instance. You do this by using the trove ``configuration-attach`` command and passing in the ID of the database instance and the ID of the configuration group. Get the ID of the database instance: .. code:: $ trove list +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ | id | name | datastore | datastore_version | status | flavor_id | size | +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ | 26a265dd-1c88-4333-b3ed-6b4e9e87ffbb | mysql_instance_7 | mysql | mysql-5.5 | ACTIVE | 6 | 5 | +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ Get the ID of the configuration group: .. code:: $ trove configuration-list +--------------------------------------+--------+-------------+--------------------------------------+ | id | name | description | datastore_version_id | +--------------------------------------+--------+-------------+--------------------------------------+ | 9a9ef3bc-079b-476a-9cbf-85aa64f898a5 | group1 | None | eeb574ce-f49a-48b6-820d-b2959fcd38bb | +--------------------------------------+--------+-------------+--------------------------------------+ Attach the configuration group to the database instance: .. note:: This command syntax pertains only to python-troveclient version 1.0.6 and later. Earlier versions require you to pass in the configuration group ID as the first argument. .. code:: $ trove configuration-attach DB_INSTANCE_ID CONFIG_GROUP_ID #. **Re-examine the database configuration** Display the ``sync_binlog`` setting again: .. code:: mysql> show variables like 'sync_binlog'; +---------------+-------+ | Variable_name | Value | +---------------+-------+ | sync_binlog | 1 | +---------------+-------+ As you can see, the ``sync_binlog`` option is now set to ``1``, as specified in the ``group1`` configuration group. **Conclusion. **\ Using a configuration group to set a single option on a single database is obviously a trivial example. However, configuration groups can provide major efficiencies when you consider that: - A configuration group can specify a large number of option values. - You can apply a configuration group to hundreds or thousands of database instances in your environment. Used in this way, configuration groups let you modify your database cloud configuration, on the fly, on a massive scale. **Maintenance. **\ There are also a number of useful maintenance features for working with configuration groups. You can: - Disassociate a configuration group from a database instance, using the trove ``configuration-detach`` command. - Modify a configuration group on the fly, using the trove ``configuration-patch`` command. - Find out what instances are using a configuration group, using the trove ``configuration-instances`` command. - Delete a configuration group, using the trove ``configuration-delete`` command. You might want to do this if no instances use a group.

commit_message:
Replace 'tenant' by 'project'

This patch replaces the occurence of 'tenant' by 'project'. There
are still some places 'tenant' have to be used. Will try remove them
when possible and necessary.

Change-Id: I37d8c2545c3086d44bb3d8bd88053fc02e00c947

commit_message:
Make json argument in container-create command positional

Currently, execute "magnum container-create" command will hangs on
because the json argument is optional.

The json should be a positional argument as this patch did.

Change-Id: I97ad2cf1c3b3e7edc978920a54edd9bb3dc9d287
Closes-bug: #1439943

commit_message:
Compare to the right heat status when bay CREATE_FAILED

Currently, we used "FAILED" when the bay create failed.
But in heat, the status should be "CREATE_FAILED", it cause the
poll_and_check method won't stop looping when one bay create
failed.

This patch change "FAILED" to "CREATE_FAILED"

Change-Id: I670b1149a04f497be9fc739398fec8c6e9f73f36
Closes-bug: #1439924

subject: Erasure Code Reconstructor
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-29 21:04:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/3fe1a7d8f9b6ffedfbae4777a143c0dd66b41f14', 'message': 'Reconstructor helpers for handoff revert case (and other misc)

In a continuing series to build up the reconstructor, this patch:

- moves the reconstructor to using its own .conf files instead of
sharing with the object server.  This is needed to facilitate its
having a proxy pipeline for using InternalClient

- add a .conf file just for the recon proxy pipeline to be shared
by all of the daemons.   It.s a little goofy and there are several
alternatives so am open to anyone who has a real issue with
this to pushing one of the alternates

- adds a helper to HEAD all primaries for a given hash to get
their fragment archive index

- adds a helper to decide which node to revert to based on
local fragment archive index and what else is out there

- changes to update_deleted() to use the new helpers

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies

The Current WIP:

- sample.conf files need to be updated
- testing, need to review the algorithms here used in
  update_deleted for sanity

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-11-18 23:14:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/82e1922ed6ccd760997ee0771c19d0e6fd243980', 'message': 'Reconstructor helpers for handoff revert case (and other misc)

** Major WIP here.  Just posting to help facilitate discussion
on some of the scenarios talked about in Paris and some
possible solutions. **

In a continuing series to build up the reconstructor, this patch
really focuses on making sure that reverting data to another
primary (based on being an old handoff or because of rebalance)
works (send the right data to the right places w/o crazy overhead
and without overwriting another fragment archive of a different
index)

- moves the reconstructor to using its own .conf files instead of
sharing with the object server.  This is needed to facilitate its
having a proxy pipeline for using InternalClient which based on
some recent design changes may/may not be needed and will be
addressed when the patch is code complete

- add a .conf file just for the recon proxy pipeline to be shared
by all of the daemons.   It.s a little goofy and there are several
alternatives so am open to anyone who has a real issue with
this to pushing one of the alternates.  If no internal client is
needed will remove this.

- added in a current "in review" node/FI pairing patch which is
functionally needed for the rest of this to make any sense

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.  Will revert any
un-needed policy_index parameter passing when this is code complete,
wanted to maintain the integrity of the patch that I merged in as
it was already tested/verified/approved

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for
EC policies now appears appended to the timestamp (for repl its
nothing).  The changes includes the required plumbing for basic
functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested
by a long shot

- added a "stamp file" (name can be adjusted later).  The idea is
that diskfile drops a zero byte file to indicate the FI number
of any object written to a particular partition.  The file is used
by the reconstructor for reverting data to the right primary without
having to communicate with other nodes or walk the whole freaking
partition tree.  When its identified the need to shovel a partition
off to somewhere else, it chooses the nodes to sync with based on
using the stamp number (I have at least one FI #n here somewhere) as
an index into the primary partition node list.

- changes to update_deleted() in the reconstructor so that it can
do its basic job of pushing data off to where it belongs once a
job has been constructed indicating such based on whether the local
partition is supposed to live here or not (same as repl)

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the
cases above

The Current WIP:

- functional developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done
(have minimally checked all of it as its being developed, the basic
functionality does work) will sanity check the design and write the
test code.

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-12-03 22:30:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/d2134fd8cdb0e29a6fb90d4ca8b8cfde32bc5789', 'message': 'Reconstructor helpers for handoff revert case (and other misc)

and without overwriting another fragment archive of a different
index)

- moves the reconstructor to using its own .conf files instead of
sharing with the object server.  This is needed to facilitate its
having a proxy pipeline for using InternalClient which based on
some recent design changes may/may not be needed and will be
addressed when the patch is code complete

- add a .conf file just for the recon proxy pipeline to be shared
by all of the daemons.   It.s a little goofy and there are several
alternatives so am open to anyone who has a real issue with
this to pushing one of the alternates.  If no internal client is
needed will remove this.

- added in a current "in review" node/FI pairing patch which is
functionally needed for the rest of this to make any sense

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.  Will revert any
un-needed policy_index parameter passing when this is code complete,
wanted to maintain the integrity of the patch that I merged in as
it was already tested/verified/approved

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for
EC policies now appears appended to the timestamp (for repl its
nothing).  The changes includes the required plumbing for basic
functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested
by a long shot

- added a "stamp file" (name can be adjusted later).  The idea is
that diskfile drops a zero byte file to indicate the FI number
of any object written to a particular partition.  The file is used
by the reconstructor for reverting data to the right primary without
having to communicate with other nodes or walk the whole freaking
partition tree.  When its identified the need to shovel a partition
off to somewhere else, it chooses the nodes to sync with based on
using the stamp number (I have at least one FI #n here somewhere) as
an index into the primary partition node list.

- changes to update_deleted() in the reconstructor so that it can
do its basic job of pushing data off to where it belongs once a
job has been constructed indicating such based on whether the local
partition is supposed to live here or not (same as repl)

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the
cases above

- new hashes.pkl format using new SuffixHashes class that supports
both replication style and EC style.  The class is mainly 2 dicts,
one indexed by suffix and one indexed by fragment number.  The
values in both cases are another dict that contains the hash info.
When stored, the class is pickled as a single dict (by suffix) to
avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand and can be changed
to be "more lazy" as we iterate on the patch...

The Current WIP:

- functional developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done
(have minimally checked all of it as its being developed, the basic
functionality does work) will sanity check the design and write the
test code.

- a lot of the internal client support may be yanked before ready
for final review.  We may only need direct client for reconstructor
which will simplify some of this patch for sure

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51

'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-12-21 18:39:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/0f9fbfa3af55f0ecd9f8fdab6b50d2a66bcd3b78', 'message': 'New hashes.pkl format and several other reconstructor related changes

** STILL WIP.  Just posting to help facilitate discussions, next steps **

In a continuing series to build up the reconstructor, this patch
really focuses on making sure that reverting data to another
primary (based on being an old handoff or because of rebalance)
works (send the right data to the right places w/o crazy overhead
and without overwriting another fragment archive of a different
index).  To that end several new ideas are introduced (note that
there are a few other reconstructor related misc items here as
well):

- moves the reconstructor to using its own .conf files instead of
sharing with the object server.  This is needed to facilitate its
having a proxy pipeline for using InternalClient (may or may
not end up keeping this)

- add a .conf file just for the recon proxy pipeline to be shared
by all of the daemons.   It.s a little goofy and there are several
alternatives so am open to anyone who has a real issue with
this to pushing one of the alternates.  If no internal client is
needed will remove this.

- added in a current "in review" node/FI pairing patch which is
functionally needed for the rest of this to make any sense

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for
EC policies now appears appended to the timestamp (for repl its
nothing).  The changes includes the required plumbing for basic
functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested

- changes to update_deleted() in the reconstructor so that it can
do its basic job of pushing data off to where it belongs once a
job has been constructed indicating such based on whether the local
partition is supposed to live here or not.

- changes to update() in the reconstructor to facilitate reconstruction.

- changes to sssync to support EC reconstruction

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction prior to sending the object over to
the receiver

- new hashes.pkl class for use by both recon and repl, see SuffixHashes.
All of the code needed to support the new style is also included and
affects mainly Diskfile, and the replicator (well, the reconstructor too
but that.s all new). The class is mainly 2 dicts, one indexed by suffix and
one indexed by fragment number.  The values in both cases are another d
ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand by the reconstructor

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the
cases above

The Current WIP:
- developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done
(have minimally checked all of it as its being developed, the basic
functionality does work) will sanity check the design and write the
test code. NOTE: existing test code has already been updated to work
with the hashes.pkl changes.

In a continuing series to build up the reconstructor, this patch
started focusing on just one thing but quickly grew as there are
many dependencies between the various smaller portions of the
reconstructor and I felt it would be easier to see them all in
this one patch than try to manage a ton of smaller ones.  We will
see how reviews go and adjust accordingly of course.

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- added in a current "in review" node/FI pairing patch which is

- changes to update_deleted() in the reconstructor so that it can

partition is supposed to live here or not.

- changes to update() in the reconstructor to facilitate reconstruction.

- changes to sssync to support EC reconstruction

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction prior to sending the object over to
the receiver

- new hashes.pkl class for use by both recon and repl, see SuffixHashes.
All of the code needed to support the new style is also included and
affects mainly Diskfile, and the replicator (well, the reconstructor too
but that.s all new). The class is mainly 2 dicts, one indexed by suffix and
one indexed by fragment number.  The values in both cases are another d
ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is

'}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-01-05 20:06:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/78c9d318a2469e9c3eb2f6e3d21bf6170b72a29e', 'message': 'New hashes.pkl format and other reconstructor changes

** STILL WIP.  Just posting to help facilitate discussions,
next steps **

In a continuing series to build up the reconstructor, this patch
started focusing on just one thing but quickly grew as there are
many dependencies between the various smaller portions of the
reconstructor and I felt it would be easier to see them all in
this one patch than try to manage a ton of smaller ones.  We will
see how reviews go and adjust accordingly of course.

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- added in a current "in review" node/FI pairing patch which is
functionally needed for the rest of this to make any sense

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for
EC policies now appears appended to the timestamp (for repl its
nothing).  The changes includes the required plumbing for basic
functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested

- changes to update_deleted() in the reconstructor so that it can
do its basic job of pushing data off to where it belongs once a
job has been constructed indicating such based on whether the local
partition is supposed to live here or not.

- changes to update() in the reconstructor to facilitate reconstruction.

- changes to sssync to support EC reconstruction

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction prior to sending the object over to
the receiver

- new hashes.pkl class for use by both recon and repl, see SuffixHashes.
All of the code needed to support the new style is also included and
affects mainly Diskfile, and the replicator (well, the reconstructor too
but that.s all new). The class is mainly 2 dicts, one indexed by suffix and
one indexed by fragment number.  The values in both cases are another d
ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand by the reconstructor

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the
cases above

The Current WIP:
- developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done
(have minimally checked all of it as its being developed, the basic
functionality does work) will sanity check the design and write the
test code. NOTE: existing test code has already been updated to work
with the hashes.pkl changes.

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51

** STILL WIP.  Just posting to help facilitate discussions,
next steps **

In a continuing series to build up the reconstructor, this patch
started focusing on just one thing but quickly grew as there are
many dependencies between the various smaller portions of the
reconstructor and I felt it would be easier to see them all in
this one patch than try to manage a ton of smaller ones.  We will
see how reviews go and adjust accordingly of course.

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for
EC policies now appears appended to the timestamp (for repl its
nothing).  The changes includes the required plumbing for basic
functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction while sending the object over to
the receiver

- guts of reconstructor sorta follow replicator but there's not a
notiong of update() and upate_deleted().  This area is WIP but
heading towards a single per part+FI job and a single job processor
that just does the right thing based on an analysis of hashes.pkl

- new hashes.pkl class for use by both recon and repl, see SuffixHashes.
All of the code needed to support the new style is also included and
affects mainly Diskfile, and the replicator (well, the reconstructor too
but that.s all new). The class is mainly 2 dicts, one indexed by suffix and
one indexed by fragment number.  The values in both cases are another d
ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand by the reconstructor

the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the

'}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2015-01-20 00:20:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/05d84c80acd5ba95c83eb9ae304c07ac5dc2d5ff', 'message': 'New hashes.pkl format and other reconstructor changes

** STILL WIP.  Just posting to help facilitate discussions,
next steps **

In a continuing series to build up the reconstructor, this patch
started focusing on just one thing but quickly grew as there are
many dependencies between the various smaller portions of the
reconstructor and I felt it would be easier to see them all in
this one patch than try to manage a ton of smaller ones.  We will
see how reviews go and adjust accordingly of course.

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for
EC policies now appears appended to the timestamp (for repl its
nothing).  The changes includes the required plumbing for basic
functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction while sending the object over to
the receiver

- guts of reconstructor sorta follow replicator but there's not a
notiong of update() and upate_deleted().  This area is WIP but
heading towards a single per part+FI job and a single job processor
that just does the right thing based on an analysis of hashes.pkl.
Currently there is a job builder that is collecting all of the info
needed (suspected) by the yet-to-be-written job processor.

- new hashes.pkl class for use by both recon and repl, see SuffixHashes.
All of the code needed to support the new style is also included and
affects mainly Diskfile, and the replicator (well, the reconstructor too
but that.s all new). The class is mainly 2 dicts, one indexed by suffix and
one indexed by fragment number.  The values in both cases are another d
ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand by the reconstructor

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the
cases above

- added ability to have multiple FI's co-exist in a single hash dir.  This is
sort of prrof-of-concept mode right now but essentially:
    - proxy will place the node index that of the node its talking to for
      get/head so that when the object server gets a diskfile object it
      can indicate which FI it wants in the event that there are others there
    - for the PUT path the FI is not needed up front when instantiating a
      diskfile because nothing needs to be opened first.  So, as before, the
      FI used to create the filename in the hash dir is from the EC metadata
      sent in the trailer of the PUT
    - "need to look at closely" changes to diskfile routines like
      get_ondisk_files() as this is where it gets a little hairy

The Current WIP:
- developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done
(have minimally checked all of it as its being developed, the basic
functionality does work) will sanity check the design and write the
test code. NOTE: existing test code has already been updated to work
with the hashes.pkl changes.

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51
'}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2015-02-03 17:47:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/36936e452076dd5e59344e2f4d9c88e7ba933bff', 'message': 'New hashes.pkl format and other reconstructor changes

** STILL WIP.  Just posting to help facilitate discussions,
next steps **

In a continuing series to build up the reconstructor, this patch
started focusing on just one thing but quickly grew as there are
many dependencies between the various smaller portions of the
reconstructor and I felt it would be easier to see them all in
this one patch than try to manage a ton of smaller ones.  We will
see how reviews go and adjust accordingly of course.

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for
EC policies now appears appended to the timestamp (for repl its
nothing).  The changes includes the required plumbing for basic
functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction while sending the object over to
the receiver

- guts of reconstructor sorta follow replicator but there's not a
notiong of update() and upate_deleted().  This area is WIP but
heading towards a single per part+FI job and a single job processor
that just does the right thing based on an analysis of hashes.pkl.
Currently there is a job builder that is collecting all of the info
needed (suspected) by the yet-to-be-written job processor.

- new hashes.pkl class for use by both recon and repl, see SuffixHashes.
All of the code needed to support the new style is also included and
affects mainly Diskfile, and the replicator (well, the reconstructor too
but that.s all new). The class is mainly 2 dicts, one indexed by suffix and
one indexed by fragment number.  The values in both cases are another d
ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand by the reconstructor

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the
cases above

- added ability to have multiple FI's co-exist in a single hash dir.  This is
sort of prrof-of-concept mode right now but essentially:
    - proxy will place the node index that of the node its talking to for
      get/head so that when the object server gets a diskfile object it
      can indicate which FI it wants in the event that there are others there
    - for the PUT path the FI is not needed up front when instantiating a
      diskfile because nothing needs to be opened first.  So, as before, the
      FI used to create the filename in the hash dir is from the EC metadata
      sent in the trailer of the PUT
    - "need to look at closely" changes to diskfile routines like
      get_ondisk_files() as this is where it gets a little hairy

- various ssync changes needed for both the reconstructor and the ability to
support multiple FI per object hash dir.  One TODO here is to address
the 'rolling upgrade' issue that currently exists with the code as is because
of a change to the ssync protocol.

The Current WIP:
- developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done
(have minimally checked all of it as its being developed, the basic
functionality does work) will sanity check the design and write the
test code. NOTE: existing test code has already been updated to work
with the hashes.pkl changes.
- address ssync interface change to handle rolling upgrades
- several conditional 'hacks' exist now to enable full functionality of the
reconstructor, many can be tweaked for elegance...

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for

functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that

heading towards a single per part+FI job and a single job processor
that just does the right thing based on an analysis of hashes.pkl.
Currently there is a job builder that is collecting all of the info
needed (suspected) by the job processor which is also currently
working for basic test cases of reconstruction and reversion.  Some
of the looping logic is still WIP in this section.

- new hashes.pkl class for use by both recon and repl, see SuffixHashes.
All of the code needed to support the new style is also included and
affects mainly Diskfile, and the replicator (well, the reconstructor too
but that.s all new). The class is mainly 2 dicts, one indexed by suffix and
one indexed by fragment number.  The values in both cases are another d
ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand by the reconstructor.  This
2nd dict is not currently used (remnant from early thinking) and will be removed

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of

    - for the PUT path the FI is not needed up front when instantiating a
      diskfile because nothing needs to be opened first.  So, as before, the
      FI used to create the filename in the hash dir is from the EC metadata
      sent in the trailer of the PUT
    - "need to look at closely" changes to diskfile routines like
      get_ondisk_files() as this is where it gets a little hairy as well
      as hash_cleanup_listdir
    - the .durable concept is introduced and partially tested in unit test
      code because of the changes needed to the 2 functions mentioned above
      to support knowing how to handle multiple FIs in the same hash dir

- various ssync changes needed for both the reconstructor and the ability to
support multiple FI per object hash dir.  One TODO here is to address
the 'rolling upgrade' issue that currently exists with the code as is because
of a change to the ssync protocol.

The Current WIP:
- developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done

ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand by the reconstructor.  This
2nd dict is not currently used (remnant from early thinking) and will be removed
shortly.

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the
cases above

- added ability to have multiple FI's co-exist in a single hash dir.  This is
sort of prrof-of-concept mode right now (some of it is ugly) but essentially:
    - proxy will place the node index that of the node its talking to for
      get/head so that when the object server gets a diskfile object it
      can indicate which FI it wants in the event that there are others there
    - for the PUT path the FI is not needed up front when instantiating a
      diskfile because nothing needs to be opened first.  So, as before, the
      FI used to create the filename in the hash dir is from the EC metadata
      sent in the trailer of the PUT
    - "need to look at closely" changes to diskfile routines like
      get_ondisk_files() as this is where it gets a little hairy as well
      as hash_cleanup_listdir
    - the .durable concept is introduced and partially tested in unit test
      code because of the changes needed to the 2 functions mentioned above
      to support knowing how to handle multiple FIs in the same hash dir

- various ssync changes needed for both the reconstructor and the ability to
support multiple FI per object hash dir.  One TODO here is to address
the 'rolling upgrade' issue that currently exists with the code as is because
of a change to the ssync protocol.

The Current WIP:
- developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done
(have minimally checked all of it as its being developed, the basic
functionality does work) will sanity check the design and write the
test code. NOTE: existing test code has already been updated to work
with the hashes.pkl changes.
- address ssync interface change to handle rolling upgrades
- several conditional 'hacks' exist now to enable full functionality of the
reconstructor, many can be tweaked for elegance...

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51
'}, {'number': 22, 'created': '2015-02-25 20:46:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/c084ad4fbe855eb63c8234738b419448f887f0ec', 'message': 'Erasure Code Reconstructor

** STILL WIP.  Just posting to help facilitate discussions,
next steps **

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- pulled in a lot of test_diskfile.py changes and plumbing from
another WIP (soon to be abandoned) patch that setup a per policy
flag to define "auto delete" or not.  That actual functionality
doesn't make sense right now but most (maybe not all) of the
policy index plumbing into various diskfile methods is needed by
this patch so I just lifted it all in tact.

- added a per policy timestamp/filename morpher so that the FI for
EC policies now appears appended to the timestamp (for repl its
nothing).  The changes includes the required plumbing for basic
functionality using the new ts/name however its not fully tested

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction while sending the object over to
the receiver

- guts of reconstructor sorta follow replicator but there's not a
notiong of update() and upate_deleted().  This area is WIP but
heading towards a single per part+FI job and a single job processor
that just does the right thing based on an analysis of hashes.pkl.
Currently there is a job builder that is collecting all of the info
needed (suspected) by the job processor which is also currently
working for basic test cases of reconstruction and reversion.  Some
of the looping logic is still WIP in this section.

- new hashes.pkl class for use by both recon and repl, see SuffixHashes.
All of the code needed to support the new style is also included and
affects mainly Diskfile, and the replicator (well, the reconstructor too
but that.s all new). The class is mainly 2 dicts, one indexed by suffix and
one indexed by fragment number.  The values in both cases are another d
ict that contains the hash info. When stored, the class is pickled as a single
dict (by suffix) to avoid pickling duplicate information.  The by_fragment dict is
built up using by by_suffix information on demand by the reconstructor.  This
2nd dict is not currently used (remnant from early thinking) and will be removed
shortly.

- updated test code to use the test rings created as part of
the patched policies and minimally added test code in some of the
cases above

- added ability to have multiple FI's co-exist in a single hash dir.  This is
sort of prrof-of-concept mode right now (some of it is ugly) but essentially:
    - proxy will place the node index that of the node its talking to for
      get/head so that when the object server gets a diskfile object it
      can indicate which FI it wants in the event that there are others there
    - for the PUT path the FI is not needed up front when instantiating a
      diskfile because nothing needs to be opened first.  So, as before, the
      FI used to create the filename in the hash dir is from the EC metadata
      sent in the trailer of the PUT
    - "need to look at closely" changes to diskfile routines like
      get_ondisk_files() as this is where it gets a little hairy as well
      as hash_cleanup_listdir
    - the .durable concept is introduced and partially tested in unit test
      code because of the changes needed to the 2 functions mentioned above
      to support knowing how to handle multiple FIs in the same hash dir

- various ssync changes needed for both the reconstructor and the ability to
support multiple FI per object hash dir.  One TODO here is to address
the 'rolling upgrade' issue that currently exists with the code as is because
of a change to the ssync protocol.

The Current WIP:
- developer test of all the stuff above.  Once that's done
(have minimally checked all of it as its being developed, the basic
functionality does work) will sanity check the design and write the
test code. NOTE: existing test code has already been updated to work
with the hashes.pkl changes.
- address ssync interface change to handle rolling upgrades
- several conditional 'hacks' exist now to enable full functionality of the
reconstructor, many can be tweaked for elegance...

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51

"}, {'number': 32, 'created': '2015-03-19 21:41:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/4e54b78bbd744dffb6da011736375f1586f725d3', 'message': "Erasure Code Reconstructor

** STILL WIP debugging w/probe tests **

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction while sending the object over to
the receiver

- guts of reconstructor sorta follow replicator but there's not a
notiong of update() and upate_deleted().  There is a single job
processor and jobs are processed partition by partition.  At the
end of processing a partition, the ECrecon will try to remove it
and it may or may not work depending on whether everything was
deleted or not (conditionally on whether the job was moving data
or syncing)

- various ssync changes that correspond to what the ECRecon is doing
and how multi-FI support is built in.

The Current WIP:
- still based on a dependency that we'll likely replace with another
patch chain so this patch will be WIP until its time to move over
- developer test of all the stuff above
- probe tests are WIP on another patch and work in conjunction with this
on.  More are being added and this patch updated as issues are found.

blueprint ec-reconstructor

Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51

notiong of update() and upate_deleted().  There is a single job
processor and jobs are processed partition by partition.  At the
end of processing a partition, the ECrecon will try to remove it
and it may or may not work depending on whether everything was
deleted or not (conditionally on whether the job was moving data
or syncing)

- various ssync changes that correspond to what the ECRecon is doing
and how multi-FI support is built in.

blueprint ec-reconstructor
Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51

commit_message:
Erasure Code Reconstructor

Here's a run down of the big things in here:

- addition of reconstruct_fa() function called from ssync_sender that
performs the actual reconstruction while sending the object over to
the receiver

- guts of reconstructor sorta follow replicator but there's not a
notiong of update() and upate_deleted().  There is a single job
processor and jobs are processed partition by partition.  At the
end of processing a partition, the ECrecon will try to remove it
and it may or may not work depending on whether everything was
deleted or not (conditionally on whether the job was moving data
or syncing)

- various ssync changes that correspond to what the ECRecon is doing
and how multi-FI support is built in but most of those are on a
different patch

There are still opportunities to add unit tests

blueprint ec-reconstructor
Change-Id: I7d15620dc66ee646b223bb9fff700796cd6bef51
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/72/131872/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [DEFAULT] # swift_dir = /etc/swift user = <your-user-name> # You can specify default log routing here if you want: # log_name = swift log_facility = LOG_LOCAL7 # log_level = INFO # log_address = /dev/log # # comma separated list of functions to call to setup custom log handlers. # functions get passed: conf, name, log_to_console, log_route, fmt, logger, # adapted_logger # log_custom_handlers = # # If set, log_udp_host will override log_address # log_udp_host = # log_udp_port = 514 # # You can enable StatsD logging here: # log_statsd_host = localhost # log_statsd_port = 8125 # log_statsd_default_sample_rate = 1.0 # log_statsd_sample_rate_factor = 1.0 # log_statsd_metric_prefix = [pipeline:main] pipeline = catch_errors proxy-logging cache proxy-server [app:proxy-server] use = egg:swift#proxy # See proxy-server.conf-sample for options [filter:cache] use = egg:swift#memcache # See proxy-server.conf-sample for options [filter:proxy-logging] use = egg:swift#proxy_logging [filter:catch_errors] use = egg:swift#catch_errors # See proxy-server.conf-sample for options

subject: Hash token only for ASN1 and PKIZ tokens
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-02 04:48:29.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_auth/user.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/django_openstack_auth/commit/7e99945cc64b8e3432965bffb57dce74312b08e2', 'message': 'Hash token only for ASN1 and PKIZ tokens

Hashing the token only works if the token is ASN1 or PKIZ.
Check the token format instead of naively checking the token
length if it needs to be hashed.

Change-Id: I1c7bb3a1b6e1da30c241a4813bf7544695bd4fab
Closes-Bug: #1439499
'}]
commit_message:
Hash token only for ASN1 and PKIZ tokens

Hashing the token only works if the token is ASN1 or PKIZ.
Check the token format instead of naively checking the token
length if it needs to be hashed.

Change-Id: I1c7bb3a1b6e1da30c241a4813bf7544695bd4fab
Closes-Bug: #1439499
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/django_openstack_auth refs/changes/94/169994/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystoneclient.common import cms as keystone_cms if (keystone_cms.is_asn1_token(self.id) or keystone_cms.is_pkiz(self.id)):

subject: Print choices in the config generator
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-27 18:37:03.000000000', 'files': ['nova/openstack/common/config/generator.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0c1c76ca8dcda3e03a7935ed07f1083d41387812', 'message': "Print choices in the config generator

One more stop-gap till we move Nova to oslo-config-generator. Copy
a bit of code to print the Allowed values in a StrOpt's choices
field.

commit_message:
Print choices in the config generator

One more stop-gap till we move Nova to oslo-config-generator. Copy
a bit of code to print the Allowed values in a StrOpt's choices
field.

Change-Id: Ifacdf9461795a8b79dd6fd49c5da68f2c3d41d61
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/46/168446/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_choice_text(choice): if choice is None: return '<None>' elif choice == '': return "''" return six.text_type(choice) if (getattr(opt, 'type', None) and getattr(opt.type, 'choices', None)): choices_text = ', '.join([_get_choice_text(choice) for choice in opt.type.choices]) print('# Allowed values: %s\n' % choices_text)

commit_message:
Fix setting default log levels

The default log level override wasn't sticking around because
oslo.config resets the config when calling CONF(). We need to use
set_default instead of setting the value directly.

Change-Id: I43e12134027a657e8f2905ef4fa866332a7fb1dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/62/165962/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: config.set_default_for_default_log_levels()

commit_message:
port_fault_status and switch_fault_status

port_fault_status and switch_fault_status implementation.
reflect the same status in neutron db from ovsdb.
raises appropriate error message while creating l2gateway connection
if switch_fault_status and port_fault_status is not UP.

Change-Id: Icc77392afeb62bd2b0b0b816a63f8f02b442b0d8
